Interaction Engine Layers¶

Setting up layers manually¶

The Interaction Engine requires special layers for operation. These layers are:

  • Interaction Layer – by default, this layer contains the interaction objects.
  • Brush Hand Layer – This layer contains the interaction hands.
  • Interaction No Clip Layer – This layer contains the interaction objects when they are not colliding with the hands. Objects can switch to this layer under certain conditions, like when the user forces their hand inside of an object.

When creating these layers, the following rules should be taken into account:

  • All layers must be unique. (You cannot have the Interaction Layer be the same as the Brush Layer)
  • The Interaction Layer must collide with the Brush Hand Layer
  • The Interaction No Clip Layer must not collide with the Brush Hand Layer
  • It is highly recommended that the Interaction Layer is the ONLY layer that the Brush Hand Layer collides with. The BrushHand layer must not collide with itself, either.

Setting up layers automatically¶

Alternatively, you have the option of letting the Interaction Manager set up the layers for you automatically. This has the benefit of being easier to use, but has some downsides. When using automatic layer generation, the layers will not be named, and so the interaction objects and hands gameObjects will look like they are on an empty layer at all times.

When setting up layers automatically, you will need to set the ‘Template Layer’ property to a layer of your choosing. This layer is used to determine the physics collision settings for the Interaction layer.
